data.title: John William Strutt PC JP (1842-1919)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for John Strutt PC JP born 1842 Maldon, Essex, England, United Kingdom died 1919 Witham, Essex, England, United Kingdom including ancestors + descendants + 1 photos + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 19 Jan 2024 | Created 12 Nov 2014

This page has been accessed 2,159 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Marriage

1.2 Death

2 Sources

Biography

John Strutt PC JP was born in Maldon, Essex, England.

Sir John Strutt was a member of the aristocracy in British Isles.

John Strutt PC JP is Notable.

John William Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh of Terling Place was born on 12 November 1842 at Langford Grove, Maldon, Essex, England, United Kingdom.

He was the son of John James Strutt, 2nd Baron Rayleigh of Terling Place and Clara Elizabeth La Touche Vicars.

Education

He was educated at Eton College, Windsor, Berkshire, England and at Harrow School, Harrow on the Hill, London, England. He graduated from Trinity College, Cambridge University, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, England, with a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) He graduated from Trinity College, Cambridge University, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, England, in 1868 with a Master of Arts (M.A.) He was invested as a Fellow, Royal Society (F.R.S.) in 1873.

Marriage

He married Evelyn Georgiana Mary Balfour on 19 Jul 1871 at St George Hanover Square, London, England. Evelyn was the daughter of James Maitland Balfour and Lady Blanche Mary Harriet Gascoyne-Cecil .[1]

Succeeded to the Title

Two years after his marriage, Sir John William Strutt succeeded to the title of 3rd Baron Rayleigh of Terling Place, Essex, England, United Kingdom, on 14 June 1873. The title was originally created [U.K., 1821].

Author

Sir John William Strutt developed the duplex theory of human sound localisation using two binaural cues, interaural phase difference and interaural level difference.

He wrote the book "Treatise on the Theory of Sound", which was published in two volumes during 1877-1878,

His other extensive 446 studies are reported in his Scientific Papers – six volumes issued during 1889-1920.

He has also contributed to the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

Renowned Scientist and Nobel Prize Winner and other Awards

In 1894 he discovered the inert gas, argon. He was decorated with the award of the Officer, Legion of Honour.

He was decorated with the award of the Order of Merit (O.M.) in 1902.

He was decorated with the award of the Nobel Prize (for Physics) in 1904. [2]

Positions Held

He was the Cavendish Professor of Experimental Physics at the University of Cambridge between 1879 and 1884.

He was president of the British Association in 1884.

He was Professor of Natural Philosophy, Royal Institute, Cambridge between 1887 and 1905.

He was president of the Royal Society between 1905 and 1908.

He was Chancellor of Cambridge University between 1908 and 1919.

He was president of the special government advisory committee on aeronautics in 1909.

Although he was a member of the House of Lords, he sparingly spent time on politics in order to devote his energies to science.

He held the office of Lord-Lieutenant of Essex between 1892 and 1901.

He was invested as a Privy Counsellor (P.C.) in 1905.

He was a Justice of the Peace.

Death

Sir John William Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh, passed away at the age of 76 on 30 Jun 1919 at Terling Place, Essex, England, United Kingdom. [3]

Succession to the Title His firstborn son, Robert John Strutt succeeded to the Barony of Rayleigh as the 4th Baron Rayleigh, upon the death of his father.
